ContentClassification.TableReference: Ales Ahcan, et al, “Slovenian Annuity Tables”, Faculty of Economics (Ljubljana, 2012) Accessed: 06/2014 from http://maksi2.ef.uni-lj.si/zaloznistvoslike/373/SAMBT_SlovenianAnnuityTables_cela.pdf.
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Slovenian Age Cohort Life Table for 1965 (SCO65)- Male. Minimum Age: 0. Maximum Age: 120
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: Historical data was used to generate the Slovenian base cohort population mortality tables for the 1965. The cohort table is then used in construction of annuity tables (See SOA Table Identities 2813-2816). Use of cohort life tables in the conjunction with annuities is typical as cohort tables are better at capturing improvements in mortality overtime. As data was only available for the period 1971 to 2008, central death rates of other European countries were obtained from the Human Mortality Database. Methodology: Log linear interpolation was used to derive the central death rates for 1945 to 1970 period. A set of smoothing procedures was then used to obtain less variability in the data. Due to the small population size, some death rates at the younger ages were equal to 0 and adjustment techniques were implemented utilizing interpolation techniques based on neighbour central death rates. At old ages, as is common in many countries, data at old ages for the Slovenian population are sparse and hence is exposed to large sampling errors. The method proposed by Denuit and Godernaiux (2005) was selected to extrapolate death rates at the very old ages. This method utilizes a logistic formula. The overall data was then smoothed with m-splines with a limiting age of 120. Specifically, weighted regression splines with a monotonicity constraint proposed by Hyndman and Ullah (2007) was used. Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 06/2014

MetaData.TableDescription: Slovenian Age Cohort Life Table for 1965 (SCO65)- Male. Minimum Age: 0. Maximum Age: 120
